issue.title: Support default zoom level for vector tiles in OGC API Tiles Driver
issue.body:
As discussed in [this](https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/issues/7934) issue , the OGC API Tiles driver is not able to read vector tiles.

## Expected behavior and actual behavior.

The expected behavior should be to request OGC API vector tiles, and receive back a dataset:

ogr2ogr -oo API=TILES test.geojson "OGCAPI:https://maps.gnosis.earth/ogcapi/collections/Daraa:AgricultureSrf"

Instead, the response is:

```
ERROR 1: Layer 'Zoom level 1' does not already exist in the output dataset, and cannot be created by the output driver.
ERROR 1: Terminating translation prematurely after failed
```

ogrinfo tells us that the dataset is available in multiple zoom levels:

```
ogrinfo -oo API=TILES "OGCAPI:https://maps.gnosis.earth/ogcapi/collections/Daraa:AgricultureSrf"
INFO: Open of OGCAPI:https://maps.gnosis.earth/ogcapi/collections/Daraa:AgricultureSrf' using driver OGCAPI' successful.
Metadata:
TITLE=AgricultureSrf
1: Zoom level 0
2: Zoom level 1
3: Zoom level 2
4: Zoom level 3
5: Zoom level 4
6: Zoom level 5
7: Zoom level 6
8: Zoom level 7
9: Zoom level 8
10: Zoom level 9
11: Zoom level 10
12: Zoom level 11
13: Zoom level 12
14: Zoom level 13
15: Zoom level 14
16: Zoom level 15
17: Zoom level 16
```

Most likely, OGR does not know which zoom to pick and throws back an error, terminating the task.

This could be avoided by picking a zoom level by default (perhaps the lowest resolution). In addition, we could also support the option `TILEMATRIX=`, which allows to specify a specific zoom level and currently only works for raster datasets.

## Operating system

Ubuntu 22.04.2 LTS 

## GDAL version and provenance

GDAL 3.8.0dev-23d309f3f4, released 2023/05/02 (debug build)

issue.title: gdal_calc : changed meaning of --format argument
issue.body:
In master the meaning of the --format argument to gdal_calc has changed from the previous/documented behaviour of setting the output file format to the generic GDAL command behaviour of outputting format details. This breaks existing scripts and differs from the documented behavior.

Looks like this was introduced by https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/commit/3c6296edfafd0e053c2c5c5e0b2034a6c3bc1fb8 , as GDALArgumentParser is now used for gdal_calc argument processing .

repo.name: gdal
repo.description: GDAL is an open source MIT licensed translator library for raster and vector geospatial data formats.

comment.body:
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/63569063/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/63569063)

coverage: 67.807%. remained the same when pulling **20133464feeedd4788111a95c8db1c9158084b65 on rouault:fix_8605** into **5d3638ac5208f7454fb7d6cf770f6cff464d6d1e on OSGeo:master**.

> on the writing side you mean? I guess we could warn if OGRGeomFieldDefn::GetSpatialRef() != crs provided in schema::metadata. If you want to do it, that's welcome

Definitely low priority. I have some time to circle back to this at the end of this quarter and will give it a go!

> Is it worth warning or erroring if the CRS embedded in the `ARROW:extension:metadata` doesn't match or is going to be dropped?

on the writing side you mean? I guess we could warn if OGRGeomFieldDefn::GetSpatialRef() != crs provided in schema::metadata. If you want to do it, that's welcome

Got it!

Is it worth warning or erroring if the CRS embedded in the `ARROW:extension:metadata` doesn't match or is going to be dropped? (No problem if that's opening a can of worms or if that kind of thing can happen elsewhere in GDAL and there's no precedent for a warning/error in that case)

> but if a stream with a GeoArrow extension column is passed to the writer, will it end up as a geometry column with the correct CRS?

no. as documented in WriteArrowBatch(), "OGR fields for the corresponding children arrays must exist and be of a
compatible type. [...] For geometry fields, they should be created either implicitly at CreateLayer() type (if geom_type != wkbNone), or explicitly with CreateGeomField()."

We could possibly have a CreateGeomFieldFromArrowSchema() that would call CreateGeomField() with the appropriate CRS if finding the geoarrow.wkb extension with a crs, but that would only be limited to drivers that support CreateGeomField(), which doesn't include Shapefile or GeoJSON that must know the CRS at layer creation time (mostly because there are single geometry column formats, and that it is easier from an implementation point of view to require it at creation time than later)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -5579,7 +5671,8 @@ static bool BuildOGRFieldInfo(
                             OGRParseArrowMetadata(pabyMetadata);
                         auto oIter = oMetadata.find(ARROW_EXTENSION_NAME_KEY);
                         if (oIter != oMetadata.end() &&
-                            oIter->second == EXTENSION_NAME_WKB)
+                            (oIter->second == EXTENSION_NAME_OGC_WKB ||
+                             oIter->second == EXTENSION_NAME_GEOARROW_WKB))

issue.title: Add layer option to return geometry columns as GeoArrow extension types when using the ArrowArrayStream interface
issue.body:
Currently, the behaviour we get when using the (fantastic!) `ArrowArrayStream` interface to OGR is that geometry columns are returned as WKB or the preliminary version of GeoArrow that existed when the Arrow and Parquet drivers were first implemented. The current format that well-known binary is returned has the field metadata key `ARROW:extension:name` set to `ogc.wkb`.

With [GeoArrow extension types](https://github.com/geoarrow/geoarrow/blob/main/extension-types.md), it is possible to attach the CRS to each geometry column. Clients that have registered the GeoArrow extension types (e.g., using [geoarrow-pyarrow](https://github.com/geoarrow/geoarrow-python)) can then ingest the stream without any extra steps (e.g., currently you have to do some manual inference/assignment of metadata to get the CRS to propagate through the rest of the pyarrow machinery: https://github.com/geoarrow/geoarrow-python/blob/main/geoarrow-pyarrow/src/geoarrow/pyarrow/io.py#L34-L54).

Perhaps an option like `GEOMETRY_METADATA_ENCODING=GEOARROW` would be appropriate? If `GEOARROW`, the `ARROW:extension:name` would be `geoarrow.wkb` and `ARROW:extension:metadata` would be `{"crs": <projjson CRS representation>}`.

I think the encoding of the geometry (e.g., using a serialized layout like WKB or a GeoArrow layout) is orthogonal to this (and probably a good deal more work since it involves building up `ArrowArray` and/or `ArrowSchema` objects rather than just building up JSON metadata). Potentially those could be future options of the GEOMETRY_ENCODING layer option...it would be particularly useful for points (for which the per-feature WKB deserialization overhead can be particularly egregious).

issue.title: Error when importing gdal
issue.body:
<!--
IMPORTANT: Do NOT use GitHub to post any questions or support requests!
           They will be closed immediately and ignored.

Questions should go to the gdal-dev mailing list at
https://lists.osgeo.org/mailman/listinfo/gdal-dev
or other support forums. GitHub issues are for bug
reports and suggestions for new features.

If you think there is an issue with coordinate order in GDAL 3.0, then it is
likely an intended behavior. See https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/issues/1974
for more explanations.

The GDAL project is made of contributions from various individuals and
organizations, each with their own focus. The issue you are facing is
not necessarily in the priority list of those contributors and consequently
there is no guarantee that it will be addressed in a timely manner.
If this bug report or feature request is high-priority for you, and you
cannot address it yourself, we suggest engaging a GDAL developer or support
organisation and financially sponsoring a fix.

-->

## Expected behavior and actual behavior.

 I expected to be able to import gdal.
The steps I did as described in [ this question](https://openradar.discourse.group/t/attributeerror-module-osgeo-gdalconst-has-no-attribute-gdt-int8/333/2) were: 
 Create a new environment:
conda create -n geo python=3.9
conda activate geo
conda install geopandas, gdal, shapely
conda install geospatial -c conda-forge

and finaly after some comment I have updated gdal:
conda update gdal

## Steps to reproduce the problem.

from osgeo import gdal

## Operating system

Windows 11 x64

## GDAL version and provenance

3.7.2
![image](https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/assets/42352209/2bd4813e-4cfe-4d9f-926b-d9e1720dc66e)

organisation and financially sponsoring a fix.

## Expected behavior and actual behavior.

 I expected to be able to import gdal.
The steps I did as described in [ this question](https://openradar.discourse.group/t/attributeerror-module-osgeo-gdalconst-has-no-attribute-gdt-int8/333/2) were: 
 Create a new environment:
conda create -n geo python=3.9
conda activate geo
conda install geopandas, gdal, shapely
conda install geospatial -c conda-forge

and finaly after some comment I have updated gdal:
conda update gdal

## Steps to reproduce the problem.

from osgeo import gdal

## Operating system

Windows 11 x64

## GDAL version and provenance

3.7.2
![image](https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/assets/42352209/2bd4813e-4cfe-4d9f-926b-d9e1720dc66e)

comment.body: DCAP_FLUSHCACHE_CONSISTENT_STATE is in master / GDAL 3.8.0 dev only . So it looks like the python bindings you've installed in ~/conda/envs/geo/lib/site-packages/osgeo are from GDAL master, but you are running against libgdal 3.7.2 . ==> closing as installation issue

issue.title: PNG file not opened to showing Map
issue.body:
Hi i am in new GIS.
currently read the shape file and want to export as image (PNG/JPEG) so that this file showing Map in C# Asp.net MVC application.

        
        Dim outputDriver1 As OSGeo.GDAL.Driver = Gdal.GetDriverByName("PNG")
        Dim outputFilePath1 As String = $"c:\Source\wissara\Sarahtml\output\test1.png"
        Dim outputDataset1 As Dataset = outputDriver1.CreateCopy(outputFilePath1, outputDataset, 800, Nothing, Nothing, Nothing)

can someone provide the code for C#, it it possible in GDAL to set background layer as google.baidu map?
